title: Part a. [0–4]
stimulusHtml:
4 points

Using Newton's 2nd law along the ramp,

1 point: For the following expression for Fm

Fm = Fg sin θ

1 point: For substituting Fg = mg

Fm = mg sin θ

1 point: For substituting Fm = IℓB

IℓB = mg sin θ

1 point: For correct answer

l = m g   sin θ l B

title: Part b. [0–4]
stimulusHtml:
4 points

| ϵ | = | − d ϕ M d t |

1 point: For correct expression for ΦM

ΦM = Bℓv

1 point: For the time deriviative of ΦM

d ϕ M d t = Bℓv

1 point: For correct use of Ohm's law to find current

ϵ = I R I = ϵ R = B l v R

1 point: For equating this expression to the expression for I from part a. and solving for v

B l v R = m g sin θ B l v = m g R sin θ B 2 l 2

title: Part c. [0–2]
stimulusHtml:
2 points

1 point: For correct expression for power

P=I2R

1 point: For correction substitution of the expression for I from part a.

P = ( m 2 g 2 sin 2 θ ) R B 2 l 2
descriptions:
Earns 0 of 2 points

P=I2R

P = ( m 2 g 2 sin 2 θ ) R B 2 l 2

title: Part d. [0–3]
stimulusHtml:
3 points

1 point: For either of the following two expressions

m d v d t = m g sin θ − I l B

d v d t = g sin θ − B 2 l 2 v m R

1 point: For rearranging terms in either expression to set up integral
For example,

d v g sin θ − B 2 l 2 v m R = d t

1 point: For integrating this expression, and applying v(0) = 0 to get answer

v ( t ) = m R g sin θ B 2 l 2 [ 1 − exp ( − B 2 l 2 t m R ) ]

title: Part e. [0–2]
stimulusHtml:
2 points

1 point: For correct answer
Yes, the final speed of the bar decreases

1 point: For any reasonable justification
For example:
Since the two resistors are in parallel across the emf in the bar, the new effective resistance is R/2. And since v = m g R sin θ B 2 l 2 from part b., then if R decreases, the speed decreases.
descriptions:
